I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: #12 - There should be more coursework in Urban Resilience within FES, but this course did not meet my expectations. Currently, Karen Seto is the main professor and with her on sabbatical this year there is really a gap in the curriculum.
Course did not meet academic expectations.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Receiving the HURRIPLAN certification
field visit
Interaction with community members.
The panel that came on the last day-- I wish this would have been earlier in the course and/or happened more frequently with different panelists.
The interactions with community members and government officials.

I liked how we dove right into the project and didn't waste too much time on background information. The course addressed a specific issue which allowed us to focus on the core problems. Most other courses at FES skim lots of different topics without allowing students to delve deeper into the subject.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: This course was not organized. Instructions were unclear and the expectations of students were constantly changing.
course syllabus
I think a couple more classes after the HurriPLAN course would have been great. They would have allowed to get better organized in the development of the primer.

The HurriPlan in itself is not enough to build a course around. It's not even readings-- it's simply slides, many of which we didn't go over. There was no structure in the readings either-- the fact the professor wanted us to come up with our own readings on Urban Resilience shows how poorly the course was planned. The readings (outside of the HurriPlan) were more around Hurricanes and Emergency Preparedness than actual urban resilience. The assignments were even more unstructured than the readings! The syllabus did not clearly line up what was due when, and many assignments or essential information about assignments were provided last minute. It was up to the class to decide on deadlines, groups, assignments. The TA really didn't do anything either. I felt as though the course name was a misnomer used just to attract students. I also wish that the panel or other parts of the course had someone with a federal gov't perspective (FEMA itself, HUD, etc.).
The intensive HurriPlan training workshop that took place over the course of a weekend.
The course was extremely disorganized and assignments were haphazardly planned. I would get more out of this course if it were structured better.
Resilience should be better understood from the academic literature rather than case study books that are 'general.'

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: effective

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: it fits well with my interest of disaster management and resilience

FES is sorely lacking any courses on resilience, disaster risk reduction, and/or climate change adaptation so I'm taking any related courses I can get. I was hoping this course would focus more on urban resilience much more comprehensively, but it had only very particular applications - specific to hurricanes, specific to the US, and specific to building and urban planners. I don't plan to be either of those, but was hoping to tackle disaster and climate change management on a greater scale. So I don't feel like this course fits in with my overall goals. Additionally, though we were supposed to produce a deliverable that would help build resilience in the East End neighborhood of Bridgeport, I question how valuable or novel our final product was for this community.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: my interest in disaster management and resilience
I wanted more urban planning curriculum in my studies.
Hurrican resilience is key to any urban planning.
I am from a disaster-prone region of the world and I wanted to learn some skills which I could potentially use in my future career in resilience building and disaster risk reduction.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes i learned a lot
No.Again "urban resilience" is a misnomer for this course.
Yes
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: sharing knowledge was helpful
I liked the group work. I learned as much from the students as I did the professor/lecturers.
Resilience is definitely a collaborative effort.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be prepared to get frustrated, but if you go along for the ride, you'll learn a few things and hopefully get to interact with a local community.
i encourage to take the course
Download/review the HurriPlan training material before signing up for the class and see what you're really going to learn about.
